org.jcvi.jillion.align.pairwise

Class PairwiseAlignmentBuilder<R extends Residue,S extends ResidueSequence<R,S,?>,A extends PairwiseSequenceAlignment<R,S>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jcvi.jillion.align.pairwise.PairwiseAlignmentBuilder<R,S,A>
  • Type Parameters:
    R - the type of Residue (either Nucleotide or AminoAcid ).
    S - the type of Sequence (either NucleotideSequence or ProteinSequence ).
    A - the type of PairwiseSequenceAlignment to build.

    public final class PairwiseAlignmentBuilder<R extends Residue,S extends ResidueSequence<R,S,?>,A extends PairwiseSequenceAlignment<R,S>>
extends Object
    PairwiseAlignmentBuilder is a class that can create PairwiseSequenceAlignments using the given query and subject sequences, and the given SubstitutionMatrix and gap penalties. This Builder can handle both local and global alignments.
    Author:
    dkatzel

    • Method Detail

      • createNucleotideAlignmentBuilder

        public static PairwiseAlignmentBuilder<Nucleotide,NucleotideSequence,NucleotidePairwiseSequenceAlignment> createNucleotideAlignmentBuilder(NucleotideSequence query,
                                                                                                                                           NucleotideSequence subject,
                                                                                                                                           NucleotideSubstitutionMatrix matrix)
        Create a new PairwiseAlignmentBuilder to align 2 NucleotideSequences.
        Parameters:
        query - the query sequence, any gaps in the sequence will be ignored by the alignment; may not be null.
        subject - the subject sequence, any gaps in the sequence will be ignored by the alignment; may not be null.
        matrix - the SubstitutionMatrix; can not be null.
        Returns:
        a new PairwiseAlignmentBuilder instance; will never be null.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if any parameters are null.

      • createProtienAlignmentBuilder

        public static PairwiseAlignmentBuilder<AminoAcid,ProteinSequence,ProteinPairwiseSequenceAlignment> createProtienAlignmentBuilder(ProteinSequence query,
                                                                                                                                 ProteinSequence subject,
                                                                                                                                 AminoAcidSubstitutionMatrix matrix)
        Create a new PairwiseAlignmentBuilder to align 2 ProteinSequences.
        Parameters:
        query - the query sequence, any gaps in the sequence will be ignored by the alignment; may not be null.
        subject - the subject sequence, any gaps in the sequence will be ignored by the alignment; may not be null.
        matrix - the SubstitutionMatrix; can not be null.
        Returns:
        a new PairwiseAlignmentBuilder instance; will never be null.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if any parameters are null.

      • gapPenalty

        public PairwiseAlignmentBuilder<R,S,A> gapPenalty(float open)
        Set the gap penalty without an extension penalty, this is the same as calling gapPenalty(open, 0).
        Parameters:
        open - the penalty score for creating a new gap; usually a negative number.
        Returns:
        this
        See Also:
        gapPenalty(float, float)

      • gapPenalty

        public PairwiseAlignmentBuilder<R,S,A> gapPenalty(float open,
                                                  float extension)
        Set the affine gap penalties to use when scoring the alignments.
        Parameters:
        open - the penalty score for creating a new gap; usually a negative number.
        extension - the penalty for extending an already open gap; usually a negative number.
        Returns:
        this

      • useGlobalAlignment

        public PairwiseAlignmentBuilder<R,S,A> useGlobalAlignment()
        Set this pairwise alignment algorithm to use a global alignment. This will force the alignment for both sequences to go from end to end. If not set, then the default is a local alignment.
        Returns:
        this.

      • useLocalAlignment

        public PairwiseAlignmentBuilder<R,S,A> useLocalAlignment()
        Set this pairwise alignment algorithm to use a local alignment. A local alignment will only include the best subsequence alignment and will not force the entire sequence to be aligned. If not set, this is the default alignment used.
        Returns:
        this.

      • build

        public A build()
        Compute the actual pairwise alignment. This method may be computationally expensive if the sequences are long.
        Returns:
        a new PairwiseSequenceAlignment instance, will never be null.

      • findMultiple

        public Stream<A> findMultiple()
        Find several alignments. If this Builder is configured to use local alignments then this method will try to find several alignments by recursively performing alignments on smaller and smaller subject sequences. Note this algorithm will find both good and poor alignments so it is recommended that the returned Stream is filtered using a Predicate that requires a minimum Score value. if this Builder is configured to use global alignments, then the returned list will be of size 1 with the same result as build().
        Returns:
        a Stream will never be null.

      • useGlobalAlignment

        public PairwiseAlignmentBuilder<R,S,A> useGlobalAlignment(boolean useGlobal)
        Helper method to programmatically use Local or Global Alignment.
        Parameters:
        useLocal - flag to say which kind of alignment to use. If set to true, this is the same as useGlobalAlignment(), If set to false, this is the same as useLocalAlignment()
        Returns:
        this
        Since:
        5.3

      • useLocalAlignment

        public PairwiseAlignmentBuilder<R,S,A> useLocalAlignment(boolean useLocal)
        Helper method to programmatically use Local or Global Alignment.
        Parameters:
        useLocal - flag to say which kind of alignment to use. If set to true, this is the same as useLocalAlignment(), If set to false, this is the same as useGlobalAlignment()
        Returns:
        this
        Since:
        5.3
